body.p: VST is a registered trademark of Steinberg Media Technologies GmbH
ASIO is a trademark and software of Steinberg Media Technologies GmbH

We have partnered with Celemony to bring you access to their Grammy-winning Melodyne, a useful timing and pitch correction and manipulation tool that integrates closely with Studio One. Studio One Artist comes with Celemony Melodyne Trial.

Before you can begin to try out Melodyne, you must first launch the standalone Melodyne application that is installed along with the plug-in versions. Once opened, press the [Try out Melodyne editor] button to start the trial process, then follow the prompts to authorize your 30-day trial.
Once the trial has been activated, you can quit the standalone Melodyne application, and then launch Studio One to begin using Melodyne Trial.
Click to enable [b]Native[/b] or [b]Hardware Low-Latency Monitoring[/b] for this Output Channel.
Opens the [b]Performance Monitor[/b] window. This monitor displays the current relative overall CPU and disk performance, as well as the performance of instruments and automation
Open the [b]Audio I/O Setup[/b] dialog, which lets you enable and configure the inputs and outputs of your audio interface, to suit the needs of the current Song
[b]Go To Previous Marker[/b]: Move the playback cursor to the previous marker in the Marker Track
[b]Go To Next Marker[/b]: Move the playback cursor to the next marker in the Marker Track
[b]Rewind[/b]: Move the playback cursor backward along the timeline
[b]Fast Forward[/b]: Move the playback cursor forward along the timeline
[b]Return to Zero[/b]: Return the playback cursor to the beginning of the Song
[b]Play[/b]: Start playback at the current cursor location
Opens the [b]Song Setup[/b] dialog, which offers many audio format, audio routing, and meta-information options for the current Song
Set [b]Master Volume[/b] for the current Song or Project. This is the final volume setting before the signal passes to your speakers or external equipment

Show/hide the [b]Info View[/b] panel, which displays all possible actions for the selected mouse tool with associated modifier key actions, as well as info about various on-screen controls when you hover the mouse cursor above them
The functions in Studio One are organized into two main pages: Start and Song. Each page is designed to help you accomplish a specific set of tasks, and each page is accessible at all times.
Open the [b]Start Page[/b], to access document management and device configuration controls, as well as your artist profile, PreSonus news feed, and links to demos and tutorials

In the top portion of the Start page, you can find two options: Create a New Song and Open an Existing Document. A Song is where you can record, edit, arrange, and mix audio and musical data. Songs are accessed in the Song page.
Show the [b]Song Page[/b], which contains all of the necessary tools to record, edit, arrange, and mix multitrack audio and instrument data
Open the [b]Add Tracks[/b] window, which lets you add one or more audio or Instrument Tracks to the current Song
[b]Record Enable[/b] the current Track, ensuring that incoming audio or performance data is recorded to that track when recording starts
[b]Record Enable[/b] the current Track, ensuring that incoming audio or performance data is recorded to that track when recording starts
[b]Record Enable[/b] the current Track, ensuring that incoming audio or performance data is recorded to that track when recording starts
Click to select an audio [b]Input[/b] for this Track
Click to select an audio [b]Input[/b] for this Channel
Click to select an audio [b]Output[/b] for this Channel
Arrangement.
[b]Monitor[/b] the input signal for the current Track
[b]Monitor[/b] the input signal for the current Track
[b]Monitor[/b] the input signal for the current Track
Click to select an Instrument or external device to receive note and control [b]Output[/b] from this Track
Click to select a note and control data [b]Input[/b] device for this Track
Click to select an Instrument or external device to receive note and control [b]Output[/b] from this Track
Click to select a note and control data [b]Input[/b] device for this Track
Opens the [b]Editor[/b] window for this Instrument
Opens the [b]Editor[/b] window for this Instrument
Begin [b]Recording[/b] on all record-enabled Tracks, starting at the current cursor position
Enable [b]Preroll[/b], giving you a period of song playback before recording starts, to help the player or singer sync up to the tempo of the song
Enable [b]Precount[/b], giving you a period of rhythmic clicks before recording starts, to help the player or singer sync up to the tempo of the song
Enable Auto-[b]Punch[/b], which lets you set a predefined start and end time for recording. This allows for easy punch-in recording, to replace small problem areas of a performance
Enable/disable the Metronome, which introduces a rhythmic click track for the performer to play to
Open the Metronome Setup dialog, which lets you configure the metronome's sound and behavior to meet your needs
Engage [b]Loop[/b] mode, in which playback runs from the start of the current Loop range to the end of the range, and then repeats until you press Stop
[b]Stop[/b] the transport, halting playback of all Tracks in the Song
Opens the [b]Record Panel[/b], a special toolbar that lets you access a variety of Instrument Track recording modes, functions, and creative tools
Switch between [b]Overdub[/b] mode (new note data is merged with existing note data) and [b]Replace[/b] mode (existing note data is deleted and replaced by new note data)
Enable to move the contents of each loop-recorded take to its own Layer in the Track
Enable to snap recorded notes to the rhythmic value set by the [b]Quantize[/b] parameter
Switch between [b]Record Takes[/b] mode (each loop of note data becomes its own take) [b]Record Mix[/b] mode (new note data merges with existing note data)
Erase only the notes added in the most recent run-through of the loop
Erase all notes in the current loop
Enable to cause incoming notes to [b]Repeat[/b], at a rate equivalent to the current Quantize setting
Enable to [b]Erase[/b] notes from the current Part during playback by holding keys down on your MIDI controller

Click to enable/disable [b]Snap to Grid[/b] mode, which causes editing actions to occur only at specified divisions in time (such as bars and beats), making editing easier when working with tempo-specific material.

Select a [b]Mouse Tool[/b] from the toolbar. From left to right, choose from [b]Arrow Tool[/b], [b]Range Tool[/b], [b]Split Tool[/b], [b]Eraser Tool[/b], [b]Paint Tool[/b], [b]Mute Tool[/b], [b]Bend Tool[/b], and [b]Listen Tool[/b].

Select a [b]Mouse Tool[/b] from the toolbar. From left to right, choose from [b]Arrow Tool[/b], [b]Split Tool[/b], [b]Paint Tool[/b], [b]Eraser Tool[/b], [b]Mute Tool[/b], [b]Bend Tool[/b], and [b]Listen Tool[/b].
Open the [b]Quantize Panel[/b], a toolbar giving you access to Quantize functions, for perfecting and manipulating timing in audio and music content
Open the [b]Quantize Panel[/b], a toolbar giving you access to Quantize functions, for perfecting and manipulating timing in audio and music content

Select [b]Grid[/b] or [b]Groove[/b] quantize mode; [b]Grid[/b] for quantizing to specific rhythmic values, or [b]Groove[/b] to extract grooves from existing audio or music content, and apply it to other Events or Instrument Parts
Select a rhythmic base value for [b]Quantize[/b] operations, also determining the look and behavior of the grid in the Arrange view
Set [b]Swing[/b] strength for quantize operations. Swing moves off-beat notes forward in time relative to on-beat notes, creating a relaxed, bouncy feel
Set the amount of quantize applied to the start of each note or transient
Set the amount of quantize applied to the end of each note in an Instrument Part
Set the amount that note [b]Velocity[/b] affects the related parameter (such as Instrument velocity or Quantize strength)

Specify a [b]Range[/b] around each grid line in which notes or transients are quantized. Notes outside this range are not quantized, letting you perfect the timing of close-to-the-grid notes without affecting others

Opens the [b]Strip Silence[/b] panel, a customizable tool that can remove silent sections of audio that fall between areas of audio content. This splits the Event into multiple Events, easing editing.

Opens the [b]Strip Silence[/b] panel, a customizable tool that can remove silent sections of audio that fall between areas of audio content. This splits the Event into multiple Events, easing editing.
Click to engage/disengage [b]Auto-Scroll[/b] mode, which causes the Arrange view to scroll automatically during playback, following playback-cursor movement
Click to engage/disengage [b]Cursor Follows Edit Position[/b] mode, which causes playback-cursor position to follow the position of the editing cursor.
[b]Tap[/b] this button once per beat to set Song [b]Tempo[/b]
Open the [b]Audio Bend[/b] panel, which gives you access to transient detection and audio manipulation functions for use with audio content
Open the [b]Audio Bend[/b] panel, which gives you access to transient detection and audio manipulation functions for use with audio content
Click to show/hide [b]Bend Markers[/b]—points within audio Events at which the audio can be timestretched
Save the current [b]Bend Panel[/b] settings as the default
Select groove quantizing [b]Program[/b]
Store groove quantizing [b]Preset[/b]
Lets you choose how playback of the current Track relates to Song [b]Tempo[/b]
Lets you choose the optimal [b]Timestretch[/b] algorithm for the current Track
Enable this option to allow any [b]Overlapping[/b] audio on the current Track to play back simultaneously, rather than cutting off at the beginning of the next Event
Click to assign this track to an existing [b]Edit Group[/b]. Many editing and mixing actions are synced across all tracks in an Edit Group, allowing you to treat them as one entity
Lets you Add, Duplicate, Rename, or Remove a [b]Layer[/b] from thecurrent Track, as well as set which layer is currently chosen for playback
Enable this parameter to make instrument data on underlying [b]Layers[/b] follow the related Event above when you move it along the timeline
Lets you apply a positive or negative time [b]Delay[/b] to the current Track to help align it in time. Range of -100 to 100 ms
Lets you [b]Transpose[/b] the pitch of all notes on the current Track (or Part), in a range between -64 and +64 semitones
Click to select from a list of automated [b]Parameters[/b], to display automation data for the chosen parameter
This displays and lets you precisely set the [b]Start Time[/b] for the currently selected Event or Part
This displays and lets you precisely set the [b]End Time[/b] for the currently selected Event or Part
If you know the [b]Tempo[/b] of the audio file associated with the current Event, you can specify it here
Lets you [b]Speed Up[/b] or slow down the tempo of the current Event, independent of other tempo settings
Lets you [b]Fine-Tune[/b] the pitch of the current Event up or down, in a range of -100 to +100 cents
Lets you [b]Normalize[/b] the volume of the current Event, so that the highest peak in the audio reaches 0 dBFS
Lets you adjust the overall [b]Gain[/b] of the current Event, in a range of -40 to +24 dB
Lets you specify the length of the [b]Fade[/b] at the beginning of the current Event. At a setting of 0 ms, no fade is applied
Lets you specify the length of the [b]Fade[/b] at the end of the current Event. At a setting of 0 ms, no fade is applied
Show/hide the [b]Inspector[/b] panel, which offers fast access to a variety of important per-Track and per-Event parameters and functions
Show/hide the [b]Edit[/b] view, which displays the currently selected Event or Part on a timeline that is independent of the Arrange view timeline
Open the [b]Macro Toolbar[/b], a special control panel that lets you customize your workflow in powerful ways, giving you easy access to often-used functions and custom command combinations
Open the [b]Macro Toolbar[/b], a special control panel that lets you customize your workflow in powerful ways, giving you easy access to often-used functions and custom command combinations
Show/hide the [b]Browser[/b], allowing quick navigation of virtual instruments, effects, and a variety of file types on your computer, including audio and musical-data files
Show the [b]Effects[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you access to all installed audio effects plug-ins and presets
Show the [b]Instruments[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you access to all installed instrument plug-ins and presets
Show the [b]Cloud[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you access to cloud-based audio and software resources
Show the [b]Files[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you access to your computer's file system, as well as special Studio One data files
Show the [b]Loops[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you access to any currently loaded audio or music loops
Show the [b]Pool[/b] tab in the Browser, giving you direct access to all the audio files that have been associated with an Audio Event in your Song
Show the [b]Home[/b] tab in the Browser, a start page giving access to each tab in the Browser, as well as the ability to search all Browser content (across all tabs) simultaneously

Arranging encompasses repositioning recorded or imported audio and musical data to change the song structure, inserting tempo or time signature changes, and many other processes. The following chapter discusses various aspects of arranging in Studio One, including importing files, working with loops, the Tempo Track, and more.
Show/Hide the Tempo Track, in which you can make tempo changes occur within your song.
[Screenshot] Time_scale_tool - The tempo track with an audio file below. The Time Scale Tool is shown, making a scaling action on the tempo to match the beat of the audio file.

The Time Scale Tool lets you quickly match a section of your tempo map with the tempo of an imported song or other audio file. This makes manual tempo mapping easier, especially when the imported file contains many shifts in tempo.

To use the Time Scale Tool, first place your audio file so that its first beat (or the first beat of any bar) is aligned with the start of a bar in your timeline. If there is not yet a tempo change marker at the first beat, create one. This becomes your starting point for the tempo map.

Then, with your cursor in the tempo track, press and hold [Ctrl]/[Cmd] to switch to the Time Scale Tool. You'll see the cursor change to look like the image above. While this tool is shown, click and drag from the start of a defined barline in the timeline (such as four bars ahead of the previous tempo marker) to the point in the timeline that aligns with that amount of bars in the audio file. Then, let go of the mouse button.

By doing this dragging motion between those two points with the Time Scale Tool, you adjust the tempo for that section to match that of the audio file. You can often visually determine the correct place to let go, but if that's not possible, you can use the Listen tool beforehand to find the right spot in your audio file.

By default, a new tempo marker is automatically inserted when you let go of the mouse button after using the Time Scale Tool. This lets you simply move on to the next set of bars you want to match with and use the Time Scale Tool again. If you'd rather not insert a marker when you release the mouse button, hold [Alt]/[Opt] along with [Ctrl]/[Cmd].
Click to show/hide all [b]Audio Tracks[/b] currently in the Track List
Click to show/hide all [b]Instrument Tracks[/b] currently in the Track List

Click to show/hide all [b]Automation Tracks[/b] currently in the Track List

Click to show/hide the [b]Track[/b] list
Show/hide the [b]Console[/b], which is the primary audio mixer and processor in Studio One
Adjust left/right [b]Pan[/b] for the current Channel, setting its place across the stereo field
Adjust Channel [b]Volume[/b], boosting or cutting output level for this Channel
Adjust [b]Master Volume[/b], boosting or cutting overall audio output
Click to mute this Channel, silencing it, or unmute it, letting signal through
Click to solo this Channel, temporarily muting all other channels so you can focus on the soloed channel(s)
Click to toggle this Channel between stereo and mono-summed
Move this slider to set output [b]Volume[/b] for this channel
Move this slider to set output [b]Volume[/b] for this channel
Click to mute this Channel, silencing it, or unmute it, letting signal through
Click to solo this Channel, temporarily muting all other channels so you can focus on the soloed channel(s)
Move this slider to [b]Pan[/b] this channel to the desired location and balance in the stereo field
Click to toggle this Channel between stereo and mono-summed
Click to mute this Channel, silencing it, or unmute it, letting signal through
Click to solo this Channel, temporarily muting all other channels so you can focus on the soloed channel(s)
Move this slider to set output [b]Volume[/b] for this channel

Click to solo this Channel, temporarily muting all other channels so you can focus on the soloed channel(s)
Move this slider to [b]Pan[/b] this channel to the desired location and balance in the stereo field

Click to toggle this Channel between stereo and mono-summed
Click to expand/collapse effects and send controls for this Channel, giving you additional control over processing and signal routing
Click to expand/collapse effects and send controls for this Channel, giving you additional control over processing and signal routing
Click to expand/collapse effects and send controls for this Channel, giving you additional control over processing and signal routing
Click to show/hide audio [b]Inputs[/b] in the Console, showing signal levels on all available audio input channels
Click to show/hide audio [b]Outputs[/b] in the console, showing controls and metering for all available audio output channels
Click to show/hide the [b]Channel[/b] list, which displays the Console channels in the current Song
Click to show/hide [b]External[/b] panel, which lists and gives you access to all enabled external MIDI devices
Click to show/hide the [b]Instruments[/b] list, which displays and gives you access to all virtual instruments in the current Song
Click to save the current show/hide state of tracks in the Console as a [b]Scene[/b], for later viewing
Click to unload and disable the currently selected [b]Scene[/b], showing all tracks hidden by that Scene
Click to view and edit the [b]Remote Bank[/b] settings, which lets you select the Console channels that you wish to control with a connected external control surface
Click to select and load a saved Console [b]Scene[/b], changing the show/hide status of Channels in the current Song to the desired configuration
Click to switch between large and small Console display mode, changing the height and available info and controls for each channel
Click to switch between narrow or normal Console display mode, changing the width and available info and controls for each channel
Click this to show/hide [b]Audio Channels[/b]
Click this to show/hide [b]Instrument Channels[/b]
Click this to show/hide [b]FX Channels[/b]
Click this to show/hide [b]Groups[/b]
Click to add your choice of [b]Effects Plug-ins[/b] (or Note FX, if applicable) to the current Track
Click to add your choice of [b]Effects Plug-ins[/b] to the current Channel
Click to [b]Bypass[/b] all Inserts (or Note FX) associated with this Channel or Event
Click to [b]Send[/b] the current Track to an available Bus or FX Channel, or to create a new Bus or FX Channel
Click to [b]Send[/b] the current Channel to an available Bus or FX Channel, or to create a new Bus or FX Channel
Opens the [b]previous[/b] preset in the preset list for the current plug-in
Opens the [b]next[/b] preset in the preset list for the current plug-in

[b]Activate[/b] or deactivate the currently displayed plug-in. Deactivating a plug-in suspends its functions and frees up any system resources it is using. To automate the on/off status of a plug-in, use the [b]Bypass[/b] function

[b]Bypass[/b] the currently displayed plug-in. This parameter can be automated, but CPU resources are not freed up when a plug-in is bypassed. For that, use the [b]Activate[/b] button to deactivate the plug-in
Opens the [b]Preset Menu[/b], in which you can create, load, export, and import plug-in presets
Click these tabs to access each plug-in in the associated Channel
Click to [b]Copy[/b] the settings of the current plug-in, to be pasted onto another instance of this plug-in
Click to [b]Paste[/b] a previously copied setting onto this instance of this plug-in
Click to [b]Compare[/b] the current setting of this plug-in to the most recently loaded preset. Click again to go back to the new setting
Click to select an [b]Automation Mode[/b] and access other automation configuration options for this plug-in
Click to activate or deactivate external [b]Sidechain[/b] input for this plug-in
Click to access Control Link [b]Mapping[/b] options for this plug-in
Click enable or disable [b]Control Link[/b] hardware control for this plug-in
Click to select a connected hardware controller device for use with this plug-in
Click this to choose an existing [b]FX Chain[/b] to add to the current Track, and access FX Chain management functions
Click this to choose an existing [b]FX Chain[/b] to add to the current Channel, and access FX Chain management functions
Click to assign this track to an [b]Edit Group[/b]. Many editing and mixing actions are synced across all tracks in an Edit Group, allowing you to treat them as one entity
Show or hide the [b]Performance Monitor[/b], displaying system performance specs and the current On/Off state of Instruments and Effects
Show/hide the [b]Marker Track[/b], which lets you place markers along the timeline, for easy identification and navigation between song sections
Add a new [b]Marker[/b] to the Marker Track at the current cursor position.
[b]Delete[/b] any Markers that are currently selected in the Marker Track.
Click this to switch the current function's [b]Timebase[/b] between Beats and Seconds. In Beats, elements move to match tempo changes. In Seconds, they adhere to their absolute position in time
Show/hide Automation envelopes, giving access to editing and management of automation data
Opens the [b]MIDI Monitor[/b] window, which lists and identifies all incoming MIDI messages sent to Studio One. Use this to analyze incoming MIDI data from external devices.

While loop editing is possible in this fashion, it lacks the control and accuracy of a dedicated wave editor. As a result, clicks and pops may appear when changing loop start and end points in this display. Adding a loop crossfade may solve this problem. This waveform display is mainly meant for monitoring or reference. If in-depth loop editing is required, a dedicated wave editor software should be used.
[b]Solo[/b] this pad, temporarily muting all other pads, so you can focus on the soloed pad
[b]Mute[/b] this pad, halting its output signal until you unmute the pad
Sample [b]Start offset[/b], to change the point in the sample at which playback starts
Sample [b]End offset[/b], to change the point in the sample at which playback ends
[b]Add[/b] a sample to a selected pad
[b]Remove[/b] the sample that is loaded in the current pad
Switch to the [b]Previous[/b] sample in the current set
Switch to [b]Next[/b] sample in the current set
Set the [b]Attack[/b] time for the Pitch Envelope for the current pad
Set the [b]Hold[/b] time for the Pitch Envelope for the current pad
Set the [b]Decay[/b] time for the Pitch Envelope for the current pad
[b]Transpose[/b] the sample pitch for the current pad
